GOD.content: Derrida starts w/ Phaedo, w/ meletē tou thanatou, w/ Socrates’ play on aïdēs (“one who doesn’t see”) & haidēs, references Levinas, Heidegger, then: care about dying as relation to self, mystery or secrecy in formation of psychē
GOD.linkedContent: Derrida starts w/ Phaedo, w/ meletē tou thanatou, w/ Socrates’ play on aïdēs (“one who doesn’t see”) & haidēs, references Levinas, Heidegger, then: care about dying as relation to self, mystery or secrecy in formation of psychē

GOD.content: philosophy from the start, vigil (veille) over death that watches out for death and watches over death (qui veille à la mort et sur elle), as if over the very life of the soul, psychē as life, breath, pneuma, caring anticipation of dying, provisional mourning, vigil as veillée and wake [in English]
GOD.linkedContent: philosophy from the start, vigil (veille) over death that watches out for death and watches over death (qui veille à la mort et sur elle), as if over the very life of the soul, psychē as life, breath, pneuma, caring anticipation of dying, provisional mourning, vigil as veillée and wake [in English]

AF.content: does the psyche transform w/ technological advancements or does it find itself better represented?
AF.linkedContent: does the psyche transform w/ technological advancements or does it find itself better represented?

HERP.content: for Heidegger, anthropology & psychology depend on metaphysics of subjectivity, interpretation of man as subject; thus, psychology did not exist for Greeks, and Christianity (w/ its new relation to philein) is 1st stage in formation of passions for subject/psychology
HERP.linkedContent: for Heidegger, anthropology & psychology depend on metaphysics of subjectivity, interpretation of man as subject; thus, psychology did not exist for Greeks, and Christianity (w/ its new relation to philein) is 1st stage in formation of passions for subject/psychology

POOF.content: friendship can’t survive its act but can survive its object, it can love the inanimate, it lives, becomes psychic, from w/in resource of survival: the beloved might be dead > re: Aristotle on mother, not needing to be known also means not needing to know if what you love is there
POOF.linkedContent: friendship can’t survive its act but can survive its object, it can love the inanimate, it lives, becomes psychic, from w/in resource of survival: the beloved might be dead > re: Aristotle on mother, not needing to be known also means not needing to know if what you love is there

POOF.content: hexis, contretemporal habitus: yoke-effect (l’effet de joug), binds 2x in same time: duration & omnitemporality, marks/hides in masking—another name for psukhé > hexis insufficient for friendship, remains a simulacrum
POOF.linkedContent: hexis, contretemporal habitus: yoke-effect (l’effet de joug), binds 2x in same time: duration & omnitemporality, marks/hides in masking—another name for psukhé > hexis insufficient for friendship, remains a simulacrum

POOF.content: analogy btwn spirit (nous) & animal body inscribes in living body habitus of this contretemps
POOF.linkedContent: analogy btwn spirit (nous) & animal body inscribes in living body habitus of this contretemps

POOF.content: Heidegger: in accomplishment of metaphysics, metaphysics becomes ‘psychology,’ psychology & anthropology are last word of metaphysics—psychology & technics go hand in hand
POOF.linkedContent: Heidegger: in accomplishment of metaphysics, metaphysics becomes ‘psychology,’ psychology & anthropology are last word of metaphysics—psychology & technics go hand in hand

VP.content: strange unity of life in Husserl: 1) biological life 2) concept of psychē is life as self-relation > the pre-transcendental becomes the ultra-transcendental, Derrida says maybe concept of life calls for another name
VP.linkedContent: strange unity of life in Husserl: 1) biological life 2) concept of psychē is life as self-relation > the pre-transcendental becomes the ultra-transcendental, Derrida says maybe concept of life calls for another name

FSW.content: our reading will let metaphoric investment “invade the entirety of the psyche”
FSW.linkedContent: our reading will let metaphoric investment “invade the entirety of the psyche”

FSW.content: memory is essence of psyche for Freud; differential forces [à la Nietzsche] become psychē and mnēmē
FSW.linkedContent: memory is essence of psyche for Freud; differential forces [à la Nietzsche] become psychē and mnēmē

FSW.content: Freud persists in accounting for psyche in terms of spacing, topography of traces, map of breaches
FSW.linkedContent: Freud persists in accounting for psyche in terms of spacing, topography of traces, map of breaches

FSW.content: for Freud, metaphor of writing appropriates problems of psychic apparatus in structure & psychic text in fabric
FSW.linkedContent: for Freud, metaphor of writing appropriates problems of psychic apparatus in structure & psychic text in fabric

FSW.content: nonspsychical system (machine metaphor) of psychical (like Heidegger’s nontechnology of technology)
FSW.linkedContent: nonspsychical system (machine metaphor) of psychical (like Heidegger’s nontechnology of technology)

FWT.content: [Derrida prefers not to get trapped btwn naturalism/constructivism] differance btwn psyché & genetico-biological laws > always something of a familial bond around birth, impossible to erase “birth,” a certain geneticism, perhaps birth is question of future, of arrival
FWT.linkedContent: [Derrida prefers not to get trapped btwn naturalism/constructivism] differance btwn psyché & genetico-biological laws > always something of a familial bond around birth, impossible to erase “birth,” a certain geneticism, perhaps birth is question of future, of arrival

DS.content: only metaphors of painting and writing are linked to psyche > in “reality,” literally, acc. Plato, writing & painting deal in copies, copies of copies, incapable of intuition of thing itself
DS.linkedContent: only metaphors of painting and writing are linked to psyche > in “reality,” literally, acc. Plato, writing & painting deal in copies, copies of copies, incapable of intuition of thing itself

POS.content: semiology inscribed w/in psychologism: reduce everything exterior about signifier, all that’s left is psyche, the phonetic sign imposes itself as “pattern” for all signs
POS.linkedContent: semiology inscribed w/in psychologism: reduce everything exterior about signifier, all that’s left is psyche, the phonetic sign imposes itself as “pattern” for all signs

POS.content: Saussure: “linguistic sign is therefore a two-sided psychic entity”
POS.linkedContent: Saussure: “linguistic sign is therefore a two-sided psychic entity”

POS.content: psychologism inscribed/prescribed w/in concept of sign itself
POS.linkedContent: psychologism inscribed/prescribed w/in concept of sign itself

OS.content: time compared by Aristotle to movement and chance, w/out being either one of them, time can only occur en tēi psukhēi > time’s analogy: what is traced (le tracé) as line, grammē
OS.linkedContent: time compared by Aristotle to movement and chance, w/out being either one of them, time can only occur en tēi psukhēi > time’s analogy: what is traced (le tracé) as line, grammē

OS.content: time, for Kant, brings difference together: only in time can opposed predicates meet in same object
OS.linkedContent: time, for Kant, brings difference together: only in time can opposed predicates meet in same object

OS.content: for Kant, inner intuition of time gives us no shape, so we make up for this via analogy: time is a line progressing to infinity > but where parts of line are simultaneous, parts of time are successive
OS.linkedContent: for Kant, inner intuition of time gives us no shape, so we make up for this via analogy: time is a line progressing to infinity > but where parts of line are simultaneous, parts of time are successive

ATIA.content: autobiographical animal, the general singulars “I” and “animal,” before ego cogito both living, both auto-affective, both moving > “I” speaks to “engage nudity w/out shame,” untenable pledge > bring in a mirror (une psyché), is the animal caught there too? or my primary mirror?
ATIA.linkedContent: autobiographical animal, the general singulars “I” and “animal,” before ego cogito both living, both auto-affective, both moving > “I” speaks to “engage nudity w/out shame,” untenable pledge > bring in a mirror (une psyché), is the animal caught there too? or my primary mirror?

PIO.content: igitur or donc [re: “Fable”] speaks for a psyche, to it/her, before it/her, on subject of psyche, which has become pivoting speculum that relates the same to the other
PIO.linkedContent: igitur or donc [re: “Fable”] speaks for a psyche, to it/her, before it/her, on subject of psyche, which has become pivoting speculum that relates the same to the other

PIO.content: Schelling’s invention, re: philosopher as an inventor of forms, still limited as invention of the same in guise of supplement of invention: man’s invention supplements God’s ideality: man as psyche of God, as supplying the lack in his revelation
PIO.linkedContent: Schelling’s invention, re: philosopher as an inventor of forms, still limited as invention of the same in guise of supplement of invention: man’s invention supplements God’s ideality: man as psyche of God, as supplying the lack in his revelation

PIO.content: here, invention caught in infinite amortization, rationalistic humanism, carries out God’s program; human invention as desire of/for God
PIO.linkedContent: here, invention caught in infinite amortization, rationalistic humanism, carries out God’s program; human invention as desire of/for God

PIO.content: supplementarity introduces (into structure of psyche) the fabulous repetition, a crossing of chance & necessity, bending performative rules while respecting them: allows other to come, or announce’s its coming, in dehiscence’s opening > deconstruction
PIO.linkedContent: supplementarity introduces (into structure of psyche) the fabulous repetition, a crossing of chance & necessity, bending performative rules while respecting them: allows other to come, or announce’s its coming, in dehiscence’s opening > deconstruction

IW.content: Derrida is calling “psyche” the psychic space of a “fantasmatic impulse” (love, hate, madness, projection, rejection etc.), & that which acts like une psyché, a large pivoting mirror
IW.linkedContent: Derrida is calling “psyche” the psychic space of a “fantasmatic impulse” (love, hate, madness, projection, rejection etc.), & that which acts like une psyché, a large pivoting mirror

IW.content: if, for Cohen, race is reducible to biologico-naturalist schema, racism not of issue re: Jew & the German, they relate through psyche, artificially, nonnaturally: alliance of religious & philosophical
IW.linkedContent: if, for Cohen, race is reducible to biologico-naturalist schema, racism not of issue re: Jew & the German, they relate through psyche, artificially, nonnaturally: alliance of religious & philosophical

IW.content: psyche as “artificial” reflection, structure of interpretation/institution [?]
IW.linkedContent: psyche as “artificial” reflection, structure of interpretation/institution [?]

IW.content: German-Jewish psyche, as a psyché always does, keeps watch over (garde) the spirit
IW.linkedContent: German-Jewish psyche, as a psyché always does, keeps watch over (garde) the spirit

IW.content: Ibn Ezra, first to doubt Moses wrote 5 books (acc. Spinoza), says: human reason is mediator btwn God/Man, there is thus reconciliation (Versöhnung) btwn God/Man, and a redemption of man’s sins > for Cohen, in Judaism, redemption presupposes human psyche [pp. 271-72 Cohen’s Judeo-Protestantism, but how does he explain Jewish duty, commandments?]
IW.linkedContent: Ibn Ezra, first to doubt Moses wrote 5 books (acc. Spinoza), says: human reason is mediator btwn God/Man, there is thus reconciliation (Versöhnung) btwn God/Man, and a redemption of man’s sins > for Cohen, in Judaism, redemption presupposes human psyche [pp. 271-72 Cohen’s Judeo-Protestantism, but how does he explain Jewish duty, commandments?]

IW.content: Jewish concept of soul, immediate relation w/ God, no mediator
IW.linkedContent: Jewish concept of soul, immediate relation w/ God, no mediator

IW.content: Kant, Jew, German: co-substantial reciprocity, their socius (alliance, spiritual symbiosis, psyche) is very socius that makes subjectum a moral being, a freedom, a person
IW.linkedContent: Kant, Jew, German: co-substantial reciprocity, their socius (alliance, spiritual symbiosis, psyche) is very socius that makes subjectum a moral being, a freedom, a person

IW.content: for Fichte, conversely, nation is an ego > relates to itself via egological subjectivity
IW.linkedContent: for Fichte, conversely, nation is an ego > relates to itself via egological subjectivity

IW.content: truth of nationality is German idealism; the German spirit is the spirit of humanity
IW.linkedContent: truth of nationality is German idealism; the German spirit is the spirit of humanity

IW.content: Cohen suspects a narcissistic infatuation in Fichte’s national ego, mirror of a certain psyché, but also room for any other self in this national self, cosmopolitan logic, national self as “We”
IW.linkedContent: Cohen suspects a narcissistic infatuation in Fichte’s national ego, mirror of a certain psyché, but also room for any other self in this national self, cosmopolitan logic, national self as “We”

IW.content: music as highest, most ideal art, its structure is pure breath, spiritus and psyche
IW.linkedContent: music as highest, most ideal art, its structure is pure breath, spiritus and psyche

TN.content: Freud: “Psyche ist ausgedehnt, weiss nichts davon (Psyche is extended, knows nothing about it)”
TN.linkedContent: Freud: “Psyche ist ausgedehnt, weiss nichts davon (Psyche is extended, knows nothing about it)”

TN.content: to say Psyche, essence, is extended [Freud], would raise (se lever) Descartes from his tomb
TN.linkedContent: to say Psyche, essence, is extended [Freud], would raise (se lever) Descartes from his tomb

TN.content: aphorisms interest us because elliptical, testamentary: keep silence sur son lit de mort
TN.linkedContent: aphorisms interest us because elliptical, testamentary: keep silence sur son lit de mort

TN.content: Nancy on Psyche: abandoned of her pose, radical solitude, alone in knowing nothing, alone for not knowing her extension
TN.linkedContent: Nancy on Psyche: abandoned of her pose, radical solitude, alone in knowing nothing, alone for not knowing her extension

TN.content: Psyche surrounded by exactitude of thinking men
TN.linkedContent: Psyche surrounded by exactitude of thinking men

TN.content: Psyche the untouchable, and not only for others
TN.linkedContent: Psyche the untouchable, and not only for others

TN.content: incarnation of Psyche is “posthumous”—what does this do to psych-ology (life of living)?
TN.linkedContent: incarnation of Psyche is “posthumous”—what does this do to psych-ology (life of living)?

TN.content: Psyche as life, breath: mourning life itself
TN.linkedContent: Psyche as life, breath: mourning life itself

TN.content: Aristotle’s Psyche is pure life of living, Nancy’s Psyche is a dead woman
TN.linkedContent: Aristotle’s Psyche is pure life of living, Nancy’s Psyche is a dead woman

TN.content: the move from body extension to extension of psyche/thinking is incommensurable > a place (lieu) neither of objective space nor extension: place (lieu) as spacing before space
TN.linkedContent: the move from body extension to extension of psyche/thinking is incommensurable > a place (lieu) neither of objective space nor extension: place (lieu) as spacing before space

TN.content: Nancy: “the incommensurable extension of thinking is the opening of the mouth” > mouth as union of soul/body; Nancy accords decisive authority to “quasi” in Descartes’ “quasi permixtio”
TN.linkedContent: Nancy: “the incommensurable extension of thinking is the opening of the mouth” > mouth as union of soul/body; Nancy accords decisive authority to “quasi” in Descartes’ “quasi permixtio”

TN.content: the “common” incommensurability of thought, which allows “psyche is extended,” is the “quasi permixtio” of body and soul
TN.linkedContent: the “common” incommensurability of thought, which allows “psyche is extended,” is the “quasi permixtio” of body and soul

TN.content: for Freud, the spatiality of space, exteriority, is a projection of an internal, psychical extension
TN.linkedContent: for Freud, the spatiality of space, exteriority, is a projection of an internal, psychical extension

TN.content: Freud/Aristotle both interested in Psyche
TN.linkedContent: Freud/Aristotle both interested in Psyche

TN.content: Psyche as Mary, beautiful for being neither dead nor alive: surviving
TN.linkedContent: Psyche as Mary, beautiful for being neither dead nor alive: surviving

TN.content: absolute mourning of Psyche (life itself) > mourning mourning, mourning w/out work of mourning
TN.linkedContent: absolute mourning of Psyche (life itself) > mourning mourning, mourning w/out work of mourning

TN.content: following Nancy’s interpretation of The Death of the Virgin, [Life comme une Morte] a “tôt” announcing an apocalypse (an end not a future) > night of nonknowledge, every desire gathers momentum, Psyche ex-posed to other, surrendered but all too soon denied to the other’s eyes
TN.linkedContent: following Nancy’s interpretation of The Death of the Virgin, [Life comme une Morte] a “tôt” announcing an apocalypse (an end not a future) > night of nonknowledge, every desire gathers momentum, Psyche ex-posed to other, surrendered but all too soon denied to the other’s eyes

TN.content: for Psyche, for a psyche altogether exposed to outside & other, there’s no autobiography: mourning autobiography (not just any mourning)
TN.linkedContent: for Psyche, for a psyche altogether exposed to outside & other, there’s no autobiography: mourning autobiography (not just any mourning)

TN.content: corps-corpse > when Freud lays Psyche on couch is he referring to the Christian body? to say Psyche is “extended,” is to say she remains tangible (against Kant, Descartes)
TN.linkedContent: corps-corpse > when Freud lays Psyche on couch is he referring to the Christian body? to say Psyche is “extended,” is to say she remains tangible (against Kant, Descartes)

TN.content: Nancy moves from Psyche is extended to body weighs (i.e. thinks) [penser, peser]
TN.linkedContent: Nancy moves from Psyche is extended to body weighs (i.e. thinks) [penser, peser]

TN.content: Husserl leads us back to purely psychic ego (Descartes) > not necessarily human
TN.linkedContent: Husserl leads us back to purely psychic ego (Descartes) > not necessarily human

TN.content: pure psychology parallels pure transcendental phenomenology
TN.linkedContent: pure psychology parallels pure transcendental phenomenology

TN.content: phenomenology finds greatest resistance where extension, place, localization are at issue > nous abordons ainsi une zone de spatialité, extension of the psyche
TN.linkedContent: phenomenology finds greatest resistance where extension, place, localization are at issue > nous abordons ainsi une zone de spatialité, extension of the psyche

NOY.content: promise of memory, memory of promise, before all psychē, all morality
NOY.linkedContent: promise of memory, memory of promise, before all psychē, all morality
